bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 30, 1948

div1.p: Lyons sends Hench the captions for the copies of Reed items to be exhibited at the Hall of Fame. She asks that he proofread them so that the program can be prepared.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 30, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
30 April 1948.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your telegram advising me of the
proper caption for the remains of Building No. 1. I know there
are many inaccuracies in the biographies. I discovered a number
in quotations from letters, etc.

When I have a good printer's proof of the program, I shall
send it to you. I have just made up a rough dummy, with cap-
tions, but before putting them into print and having to pay for
“author's corrections” I wonder whether you would be good enough to
bear with me while I give you the captions and courtesy lines for the
various data I am reproducing. If they do not seem correct to you
in any respect, please do not hesitate to say so, for now is the time,
before they are put into type. The program set-up will be more or
less, as follows:

I regret exceedingly that this letter is not more intelligible,
but I feel certain that you will understand what I am trying to convey to
you. It is now nearly 7:00 P.M. and I have been out of the office nearly
all day which accounts for the haste. I am anxious to get it off to you,
however, so that you have it over the weekend.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons. Dr. Philip S. Hench
